JoeB: Your first sentence: Yes, and to do it in time to get them elected you have to be aggressive beyond anything you, clearly, by what you said in both your comments, could not possibly understand. If it were so simple, it would already have been done.

Your second sentence: Calling lazy, incompetent, inexperienced, and cowardly people names OFTEN, not rarely, entices them to take action.

Professionals like cops, firemen, and soldiers are trained to act and react to specific stimuli. The more wide ranging their training, the better their response.

Probably the people on the platform were shocked into inaction or they suffered from a diffusion of responsibility. If someone had shouted "Let's help him" and moved into action, the story would be different. More likely, they were not paying attention, unaware of these two men until it was too late.

I hate the subway sign, "if you see something, say something". I can only imagine how false alarms are called into 911. Yet, all New Yorkers should be aware of their surroundings, instead of being in our little world while in public.
As a life long runner, I can attest to the fact that one can run faster if one is not multitasking by taking pictures while running.

Yelling "HELP HIM" may have helped -- and yelling to him to drop down between or beside the tracks may have helped.  Extending a hand -- may have helped -- and may have as others have suggested, ended with two people on the tracks.

When some like this happens right in front of you, you automatically freeze for a second or two. Then like myself, you think "what can I do' and judge if you can do something. But some, like those soldiers who have acted immediately in the heat of battle just seem to have some way to do what others can not, do so without any hesitation.

I know for myself, a the minimum I would have yelled "Help him." I have done so in the past, but not in such dire circumstances. Even so, having been on many rock climbs over the years, you are prepared to take quick action if the situation calls for it.
So I find it difficult that no one there could even shout "Help him," that does not take a hero, only awareness that someone needs help right now.

I heard the photographer on NPR a day ago. He said he was running toward the victim and just had the camera in front of him taking pictures as he ran, but was not close enough to help in time, and having seen the man killed, did not want to talk about it as he kept visualizing it when he did.

There must be several people who were there, that could have helped and did not. they will have to live with that memory the rest of their lives. How would you live with that?

And if we learn to see what we all have in common with one another, what some religionists conceptualize as the spark of divinity in all of us, it can become easier to help one another. A person develops the habit of compassion from developing habits of mind and heart, I think. How we think about people every day and in all circumstances is important.

For me, albeit not a Christian, that is at least part of the message of the "no room at the inn" chapter in the story of Christmas. It's not just that you never know when the person you are asked to help will turn out to be some holy person, but that we are in an important way all holy people worthy of one another's compassion. I think where we draw our lines about providing actual material help will change as a result of a more basic adjustment to our mindset.

I do not know what I would do in that instant. I would like to think that I would be a hero perhaps stepping in before Ki-Suck Han was pushed on the tracks. While a split-second decision to be a hero can save a life, in other cases it creates more tragedy: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/27/us/california-3-in-family-die-after-do...

I have long maintained that
>> We don’t really know how we’d act until the moment is upon us.
is the worst moral cop-out after "let someone else do it."

By considering the facts and the moral issues of any situation, it is possible to think through a response. We are then, at very least, better prepared than if we have not had the discussion.

A few weeks ago, some of us were asked if we would jump into rough surf to save our dog (based on a reported drowning tragedy). My reaction was "No, I have many other animals dependent on me and could not risk leaving them uncared for." Another responder said, "Yes, but would you stop to think of them in that situation, or would you react emotionally and go after the dog?"

Immediately our choices became clearer. We wouldn't BE in that situation: none of us would let our dog off the leash near rough surf. Perhaps before this discussion, we might have, but now for sure, we won't. Do you see how this whole thinking-it-through thing works?

In our thrill-seeking culture, one principle might well be taught more widely: we have an ethical duty to ourselves and those who depend on us, to look out for our own safety. I don't know quite how to say this without sounding callous toward Mr Han: certainly this is not to imply any fault on his part.

But another lesson about "What-you'd-do-if" is: walk away from crazy people... even if it means having to take a later train.

"We don’t really know how we’d act until the moment is upon us."

That is true enough. However, the sum total of our upbringing and education is what prepares us for the unexpected. What we learn at home, school, and everywhere we spend our time, forms our opinion and our reactions - whether they are immediate or delayed.

"Sadly, the science says we’re more likely to do nothing than respond like Wesley Autrey."

That is sad. We can help transform these scientific findings by teaching philosophy and ethics in classrooms all over America, from a young age. Extreme cases such as the ones you discuss here, are a part of the curriculum in philosophy and ethics classes in colleges around the country. Classroom exercises involving textbook or real life examples are useful. They stay with you for a lifetime. Person A is in situation B that causes person C to... Was if the appropriate response? What if...

It's a pity we wait until college to teach philosophy. We should do it starting at a young age. Conditioning people to think more critically and humanely can only help. Surely that is the place of education.

Some considerations:
1. The victim had been drinking. Was he coherent? Was he listening to people? Did he speak English? Did anyone urge him to run away from the train, and he not understand?
2. The perpetrator was still present on the platform. Was he still a threatening presence? It's been reported he approached the photographer in a threatening manner because of the camera flashes... could anyone be sure he did not have a knife or a gun?
3.The photographer was a distance away and was carrying 20 pounds of photo equipment on his back. Could he have unstrapped, dumped the backpack and camera, and run to help in time? Or did he only have time to use the tool in his hands - a camera with flash?
4. The train driver said he slowed down because of the strobe flashes. Could we not credit the photographer for taking action that was helpful, if not enough to save a life?
5. This is not the first victim-on-the-tracks incident... yet so much vitriol is directed at a bystander, instead of the MTA, which has not put in place ANY safeguards (other than lip service)... or the NYPD, which has still not placed security on subway platforms... or the Mayor, who could have improved our mental health and homeless services... or the Governor, or the NY Senate and Assembly... NO AGENCY has addressed the safety of people on the platform.

And, BTW, The New York Post wrote the headline and caption, not the photographer. Mr. Murdoch's true contempt for humanity is ever on display in its pages.

RoughAcres, your comment is perfect.  The focus must remain on this as a civil rights issue, which has nothing to do with whether one approves of other people's actions on a personal level.  The granting of civil rights should never be a matter of majority rules, although that is changing, but of equality, fairness, and the Constitution.

Frankly, I don't care about their hearts; several Justices have amply demonstrated they are immune to emotional appeals of right and wrong.

I care they uphold the United States Constitution, which guarantees Equal Protection under the law. And that includes the right to participate in a civil contract - which is what marriage is, UNDER THE LAW - and to receive the benefits inherent in that contract.

I care they uphold JUSTICE, as originally conceived under the Constitution.

As individuals, they are free to follow their own hearts... into a same-sex marriage, if they want, or to a church which preaches hate, intolerance, superiority, or bigotry.

But as Supreme Court Justices, they will thread that narrow space where Dred Scott awaits... and History will judge them as harshly as those Justices, if they fail.

At a time when marriage institution is staging a comeback in American society, it's logical to expect that even the apex court wouldn't perhaps hesitate to put its imprimatur on marriage,the same-sex or otherwise, facilitating a happy reunion of couples.
